DOC.HEAD: 200 Soviet Deputies Storm Out Over Georgian Deaths; Ligachev Accused
DOC.TEXT: About 200 deputies stormed out of the Soviet Congress on Sunday to protest a defense of the army's brutal crackdown on ethnic unrest in the republic of Georgia. It took a personal appeal by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to bring them back. The discussion also implicated conservative Politburo member Yegor K. Ligachev in the decision to send troops against Georgian protesters in April. Nineteen protesters died when soldiers armed with shovels, clubs and gas charged them. Another person was shot to death later for violating a curfew. Delegates condemned those violent tactics on Sunday. Georgians, Balts, progressive deputies and others left the hall to protest a speech by the chief military prosecutor, Alexander Katusev, who defended the Soviet troops. Katusev's speech followed a congressional commission's report blaming the army, local party leadership and Ligachev for the incident. Ligachev chaired a meeting of top party leaders two days before the clash that decided to back Georgian party leaders' request for military help in breaking up the long-running protest, commission Chairman Anatoly Sobchak said. Sobchak read a letter from Ligachev admitting that when the leadership discussed the protest in the Georgian capital, Tbilisi, Interior and Defense Ministry officials were informed of ``the need to provide forces and means in case of dangerous and life-threatening events.'' But Ligachev said in the letter he went on vacation the next day and only learned the extent of the violence from a television report afterward. ``If some leader makes a decision, I'd like to say he bears responsibility for that decision whether he finds out about its results on television or in his office,'' Sobchak said. The Georgians and other deputies left the 2,250-member Congress of People's Deputies after Katusev portrayed the Georgian pro-independence protesters as armed subversives who provoked the violence. Minutes later, Gorbachev, surrounded by security men and reporters, emerged into the lobby and sought out the Georgian delegates, some of them in tears, near the cloakroom. ``Why are they persecuting the Georgian people?'' a Georgian teacher, Natella Bokuchava, asked Gorbachev. ``Defend us! Our children are watching us.'' Gorbachev soothed the Georgians with general remarks about ethnic tolerance, and after they returned to the hall he made a conciliatory speech assuring them of the high respect of the Congress and the country. Congress later passed a resolution condemning the use of violence against the Georgian protesters. Historian Yuri Afanasyev, a leader of a fledgling opposition group, said he thought the walkout illustrated ``the further consolidation of democratic forces.'' Several dozen Baltic deputies have walked out of the Congress occasionally to protest their helplessness as a vastly outnumbered minority, but this was by far the largest walkout since the Congress opened its first session in May. In other action on the last day of its 12-day session, Congress: _Followed the lead of Gorbachev and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze in condemning the Kremlin's decision to send Soviet troops into Afghanistan 10 years ago. The panel that examined the decision said only four people were involved, all of them now dead: then-leader Leonid Brezhnev, Defense Minister Dmitri Ustinov, Foreign Minister Andrei Gromyko and KGB chief Yuri Andropov. One deputy proposed the commission consider stripping all privileges from their widows and families. _Was told that the Health Ministry's network of hospitals and sanitariums reserved for the top party and government elite would be abolished and given to the public by Jan. 1. Yevgeny Primakov, head of the panel on privileges, also said the number of country houses and cars used by officials would be cut. _Passed a resolution condemning the 1939 Soviet-Nazi pact that led to the parceling up of much of Eastern Europe, including the Baltic states. Legislatures in the Baltic republics have already condemned the pact.
